article.title: Spaceflight-Induced Gene Expression Profiles in the Mouse Brain Are Attenuated by Treatment with the Antioxidant BuOE
funding: NASA Space Biology grant, grant number NNX15AB41G, NASA 80NSSC18K0310, and LLU Department of Basic Sciences
article.abstract: The demands of deep space pose a health risk to the central nervous system that has long been a concern when sending humans to space.

sections.introduction: Radiation exposure and other stressors experienced during extended deep-space missions have the potential to compromise the function of many bodily systems [1,2,3].
sections.methods: Ten-week-old C57BL/6 male mice were launched at the Kennedy Space Center (KSC) and spent 35 days aboard the International Space Station (ISS).
sections.results: We performed in situ RNA assays in the brains of mice subjected to spaceflight (FLT), as well as grounded controls (GC), using DSP.
sections.discussion: Our results revealed common and region-specific gene expression changes in the brain due to spaceflight, with the most robust changes observed in the hippocampal CA 1 and DG regions.

experimental_factors.tissue: cortex, frontal cortex, corunu ammonis i, dentate gyrus
experimental_factors.tissue_raw: cortex, frontal cortex, corunu ammonis i, dentate gyrus

article.insights_summary: Our results revealed common and region-specific gene expression changes in the brain due to spaceflight, with the most robust changes observed in the hippocampal CA 1 and DG regions. The antioxidant BuOE attenuated the effects of spaceflight on gene expression in the brain.
article.acknowledgments: Sungshin Choi contributed significantly to the success of our study and we greatly appreciate their support.
